column5: As typical in late season the perch are most scattered and often in smaller schools but the action can still be great if your willing to move around a bit and try different things.... the past couple of weeks I have taken folks out on perch trips between trout and whities and done well 3-5 KM out from beaverton working in the 28 to 35ft depths. Super light lines (2lb) are key this time of year as the fish are really finicky. Small shinners on Gold hooks and spikes (maggots) on micro jigs and small jigging raps have accounted for great catches. Remember to be flexible and keep moving around on the flats... the fish are there big time... here are a couple of pics from trips the past few days....   http://profishntanglingservices.com/MyPict.../100_0005-5.jpg http://profishntanglingservices.com/MyPict.../100_0028-5.jpg http://profishntanglingservices.com/MyPict.../100_0009-5.jpg  Be careful and safe out there..... lots of slush in some area's!   Best of luck and good fish'n.... Greg.
Greg, another great post!  BTW which GPS unit did you end up getting to replace the one that went down the hole?  Stan
Do U think 10 lb Fluorocarbon is OK?

The man said light line 2 lb test. I would go with what he said. I was out at beaverton and using 4 lb test and the other guys that were with me were using 6 and 10 and I caught fish at a rate of at least 2 to 1 on both of them put together. Plus when a guy has as many posts on here with good catches as Greg does I wouldn't question what he's saying. That's why he gets paid to take people fishing, cause he knows what he's talking about. ATF
I gotta fix it...hope it's ok with ya, if not let me know.  There ya go Greg!         Tony
Did I say Flurocarbon? Might be a diff between Monofilament and Flurocarbon, do ya think?
I would think he posts the link instead of the pictures so people have a choice as to whether or not they want to view them all, helping the people on dailup
People are still on dial-up?  Good point, I'll leave it next time.  Tony
